awd_titl_txt: Novel Framework for Incorporating Consumer Preferences and Public Goals into Engineering Design Applied to Energy Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
What drives consumers to choose to adopt products that protect common pool resources rather than continuing with current inefficient and/or polluting methods? And how can designers create products that encourage adoption despite social and financial barriers? Understanding and modeling of user choice and behavior is common in engineering design efforts to predict market share, user preference, and optimal design for consumer products where purchase motivation is plentiful. Yet these valuable tools are less commonly, and notably less easily, applied to the design of products where user uptake is key to meeting public social, environmental, economic, and security goals. For example, smart and efficient appliances and vehicles can provide significant energy savings but may offer reduced convenience and be costly to the user. Yet these technologies will only have an impact if they are desirable and affordable enough to encourage adoption by a large fraction of users, and simultaneously perform well enough to meet the public goals of society at large. This delicate balance often is difficult to achieve due to the complex system of constraints, interrelated variables, conflicting objectives, and diverse market segments. The findings of this study will help designers to develop engineered products that are likely to achieve consumer adoption levels required to realize public goals. This project also will engage students through a unique course on rural household energy and related study-abroad opportunities. The course will cover issues addressed in this research and provide students experience with fieldwork techniques needed to understand rural and underserved communities. 

The objective of this research is to create and demonstrate a modeling framework that enables a more rigorous integration of consumer preference and public goal considerations into engineering design decisions. This will be achieved through a novel integration of techniques from user-centered design, computational social sciences, environmental psychology, usage context-based design, and agent-based modeling. The general framework will be demonstrated extensively in the context of designing household energy-related technologies. A multidisciplinary team of collaborators will combine new and existing real-world data with models of the current state of the user environment, technological options, potential actions and strategies, social norms, and utility functions to predict the consumer attitude, choice, and adoption behavior. This adoption model will be integrated into an existing systems-level model developed by the PI with prior NSF support to predict the outcomes of technological strategies in terms of a holistic set of objectives. Simulation results will inform engineering designers about the complex outcomes generated by various strategies across a community energy system.

por.por_cntn:
No matter how well a design performs on the bench or in the lab, the actual social, environmental, and economic impacts are entirely dependent the user’s adoption and engagement with the product. The objective of this research was to create and demonstrate a framework that enables a more rigorous integration of consumer preference and public goal considerations into engineering design decisions. We achieved this objective through four major contributions:

  1. Developed and executed a survey based on the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and its ability to capture the attitudes, behavioral control, and social norms of a user that dictate their choice to adopt or reject an environmentally beneficial product.
  2. Used the results of the TPB study to develop utility functions to inform an Agent Based Model to simulate the impacts of design decisions on adoption over time under the influence of social networks.
  3. Created and published a testing protocol for usability, a key driver of adoption, to provide designers a way to ensure the usability of their products before proceeding to detailed design and scale. Usability is critical, particularly in design for global development, where many well-meaning technology interventions have failed due to poor user uptake and sustained use.
  4. Developed and validated a sensor-based method to quantify impact of technologies when placed in households in terms of fuel savings. This metric enables a better understanding of how technologies perform and therefore how they might be modified at the design stage to optimize performance, as well as providing data needed to generate  results-based financing.

The outcomes of this project contribute to our discipline’s ability to quantitatively incorporate user behavior into system models for engineering design to allow for more informed design descisions earlier in the design process. Introducing the Theory of Planned Behavior paired with agent-based modeling as a method to predict technology adoption soon led to its application to other design areas and was soon used by other NSF grantees. The usability protocol is now included in the ISO field testing protocols for cookstoves, and the sensor-based method is being applied and promoted globally in clean cooking sector.

As a result of this award, six graduate students (4 MS, 2 PhD, two of whom earned dual degrees in engineering and applied anthropology) and two undergraduate students engaged in research and data collection in four countries (Guatemala, Uganda, Nepal, Malawi) through collaboration with six international organizations/NGOs, including an INTERN supplement. Ten peer reviewed journal publications, eight conference proceedings, and five graduate theses or dissertations were generated from this work, with several more in review or preparation. The students trained on this project now possess expert-level knowledge related to integrating user behavior into design and/or impact assessment and have gone on to diverse positions in design science, energy, and humanitarian engineering, including job offers with project partner organizations.
